Whether you are designing DC or AC systems, our kW to Volts calculator delivers accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: DC: 2 kW at 80 A gives V = (2 × 1000) / 80 = 25 V. Single-phase AC: 5 kW at 20 A with PF 0.8 gives V = (5 × 1000) / (20 × 0.8) = 312.5 V. Three-phase AC: 10 kW at 15 A with PF 0.85 gives V = (10 × 1000) / (√3 × 15 × 0.85) ≈ 453.4 V (line-to-line). DC 1 kW at 10 A: V = 1000 / 10 = 100 V.

items.question: What is the formula to convert kW to Volts?
items.answer: For DC: V = (kW × 1000) / I. For single-phase AC: V = (kW × 1000) / (I × PF). For three-phase AC: V = (kW × 1000) / (√3 × I × PF), where V is voltage in volts, kW is power, I is current in amperes, and PF is power factor. The three-phase result is line-to-line voltage. DC does not use power factor.

items.question: Do I need power factor for DC?
items.answer: No. Power factor applies only to AC. For DC, V = (kW × 1000) / I. You need only kilowatts and current. Common DC applications include batteries, solar, and EV systems at 12V, 24V, 48V, or higher.

items.question: What is the difference between single-phase and three-phase voltage results?
items.answer: Single-phase uses V = (kW × 1000) / (I × PF). Three-phase uses V = (kW × 1000) / (√3 × I × PF); the result is line-to-line voltage. Three-phase delivers more power at lower current, so for the same kW and amps, three-phase voltage is higher than single-phase.

items.question: What voltage does the three-phase result represent?
items.answer: The three-phase formula gives line-to-line (phase-to-phase) voltage, not phase-to-neutral. Common line-to-line values are 208V, 240V, 380V, 400V, 415V, 480V. Use this value when sizing equipment or checking distribution voltage.

DC has no power factor.

content.heading: How to Convert kW to kWh
content.paragraph1: Converting kilowatts (kW) to kilowatt-hours (kWh) is a fundamental calculation in energy and electrical systems. Kilowatts represent power—the rate at which energy is used or delivered—while kilowatt-hours represent energy—the total amount of work done over time. The conversion is straightforward: energy equals power multiplied by time. Our free kW to kWh calculator provides instant, accurate results for estimating consumption, run-time, or energy output.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: kWh = kW × hours, where kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, kW is power in kilowatts, and hours is the duration in hours. For example, a 2 kW device running for 3 hours uses 2 × 3 = 6 kWh. A 0.5 kW appliance running for 24 hours uses 0.5 × 24 = 12 kWh. You can use decimal hours (e.g. 1.5 for 1 hour 30 minutes). This relationship applies to any electrical load: motors, heaters, HVAC, EV charging, solar production, or batteries.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is used in many practical applications: estimating electricity consumption and utility bills, sizing batteries or backup systems, calculating run-time of appliances or equipment, comparing energy costs, understanding solar PV or wind output over time, and planning EV charging. Knowing how to convert kW to kWh helps you make informed decisions about energy use, efficiency, and cost.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts kilowatts and time in hours as inputs, applies the formula kWh = kW × hours, and outputs energy in kilowatt-hours. Whether you are working with residential loads, commercial equipment, renewable generation, or storage, the kW to kWh calculator delivers accurate, instant conversions to support your energy calculations.
content.exampleText: 2 kW for 5 hours: kWh = 2 × 5 = 10 kWh. 1.5 kW for 24 hours: kWh = 1.5 × 24 = 36 kWh. 10 kW for 0.5 hours (30 min): kWh = 10 × 0.5 = 5 kWh. 0.1 kW (100 W) for 10 hours: kWh = 0.1 × 10 = 1 kWh. A 3 kW heater running 8 hours per day uses 3 × 8 = 24 kWh per day.

items.question: What is the formula to convert kW to kWh?
items.answer: The formula is kWh = kW × hours, where kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, kW is power in kilowatts, and hours is the time in hours. Energy equals power multiplied by time. For example, 2 kW for 3 hours gives 2 × 3 = 6 kWh.

items.question: What is the difference between kW and kWh?
items.answer: kW (kilowatts) is power—the rate of energy use or delivery. kWh (kilowatt-hours) is energy—the total amount used over time. A 1 kW device running for 1 hour uses 1 kWh. Running for 10 hours uses 10 kWh.

items.question: Can I use decimal hours (e.g. 1.5 for 1h 30min)?
items.answer: Yes. Enter hours as decimals: 1.5 = 1 hour 30 minutes, 0.5 = 30 minutes, 0.25 = 15 minutes. The calculator uses kWh = kW × hours, so 2 kW for 1.5 hours gives 3 kWh.

items.question: How do I estimate my electricity bill from kW and hours?
items.answer: First convert kW to kWh using kWh = kW × hours. Multiply kWh by your utility’s rate per kWh (e.g. $0.12/kWh) to get the cost. Example: 24 kWh × $0.12 = $2.88 for that period.

content.heading: How to Convert kWh to kW
content.paragraph1: Converting kilowatt-hours (kWh) to kilowatts (kW) is a common calculation when analyzing energy consumption and determining power ratings. Kilowatt-hours represent energy—the total amount of work done over time—while kilowatts represent power—the rate at which energy is consumed or delivered. The conversion requires knowledge of the time duration over which the energy was consumed or delivered. Our free kWh to kW calculator provides instant, accurate conversions for your electrical and energy calculations.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: kW = kWh / hours, where kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, hours is the time duration, and kW is power in kilowatts. For example, if a device consumes 10 kWh of energy over 5 hours, the average power is 10 / 5 = 2 kW. This calculation is essential for understanding the power rating of devices, analyzing electricity bills, sizing electrical systems, and comparing energy efficiency of different appliances.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is critical in many applications: determining the power rating of appliances from energy consumption data, calculating power requirements for electrical circuits, analyzing electricity usage patterns, sizing batteries and power supplies, understanding energy efficiency ratings, and estimating operating costs. For example, if your electricity meter shows 24 kWh consumed over 12 hours, the average power draw was 24 / 12 = 2 kW. This helps identify high-consumption devices and optimize energy usage.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts kilowatt-hours and time duration as inputs, applies the formula kW = kWh / hours, and provides the power in kilowatts. Whether you're analyzing household energy consumption, sizing solar systems, calculating battery discharge rates, or comparing appliance efficiency, our kWh to kW calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your energy management and electrical design needs.
content.exampleText: 10 kWh over 5 hours: kW = 10 / 5 = 2 kW. 24 kWh over 12 hours: kW = 24 / 12 = 2 kW. 6 kWh over 4 hours: kW = 6 / 4 = 1.5 kW. 36 kWh over 24 hours: kW = 36 / 24 = 1.5 kW. If a device uses 12 kWh in 8 hours, the average power is 12 / 8 = 1.5 kW.

items.question: What is the formula to convert kWh to kW?
items.answer: The formula is kW = kWh / hours, where kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, hours is the time duration, and kW is power in kilowatts. This converts energy consumed over time to average power. For example, 10 kWh over 5 hours equals 10 / 5 = 2 kW.

items.question: What is the difference between kWh and kW?
items.answer: kWh (kilowatt-hours) is energy—the total amount of work done over time, measured in your electricity bill. kW (kilowatts) is power—the rate at which energy is consumed or delivered at any moment. Think of it like distance vs. speed: kWh is like miles traveled, kW is like miles per hour. 1 kWh equals 1 kilowatt used for 1 hour.

items.question: Why do I need the time duration for this conversion?
items.answer: Energy (kWh) and power (kW) are related by time. The same energy can be delivered at different power levels depending on the time: 10 kWh over 1 hour is 10 kW, but 10 kWh over 5 hours is only 2 kW. Without knowing the time, you cannot determine the power rating.

items.question: How can I use this calculator to analyze my electricity bill?
items.answer: If your electricity bill shows you consumed 300 kWh in a month (approximately 720 hours), your average power consumption was 300 / 720 = 0.417 kW (417 watts). This helps you understand your baseline power usage. You can also calculate power for specific appliances: if a device uses 18 kWh per day (24 hours), it draws 18 / 24 = 0.75 kW (750 watts).

items.question: Can I convert kW to kWh?
items.answer: Yes, you can convert kW to kWh using the formula: kWh = kW × hours, where kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, kW is power in kilowatts, and hours is time in hours. This is the reverse of converting kWh to kW. For example, if a device operates at 2 kW for 5 hours, it consumes 2 × 5 = 10 kWh.

content.heading: How to Convert kW to VA
content.paragraph1: Converting kilowatts (kW) to volt-amperes (VA) is essential in electrical engineering and power systems. Kilowatts represent real power—the actual work done by an electrical load—while volt-amperes represent apparent power—the total power delivered by the source, including both real and reactive components. The conversion requires the power factor (PF), which is the ratio of real power to apparent power. Our free kW to VA calculator provides instant, accurate conversions for sizing equipment, transformers, and generators.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: VA = (kW × 1000) / PF, where VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, kW is real power in kilowatts, and PF is the power factor (a value between 0 and 1). For example, a 5 kW load with a power factor of 0.8 requires 5000 / 0.8 = 6250 VA of apparent power. A lower power factor means higher apparent power is needed to deliver the same real power. The power factor indicates how efficiently the electrical system converts apparent power to useful work: a PF of 1.0 (unity) is 100% efficient; lower values indicate reactive power losses.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is critical in many applications: sizing transformers and generators to ensure adequate capacity for real loads, designing electrical distribution systems and UPS units, calculating circuit breaker and conductor ratings, understanding motor and inductive load behavior, and planning power capacity for commercial and industrial facilities. Knowing how to convert kW to VA helps you select correctly sized equipment, avoid overloading, and optimize energy efficiency.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts kilowatts and power factor as inputs, applies the formula VA = (kW × 1000) / PF, and outputs apparent power in volt-amperes. Whether you are working with motors, transformers, generators, UPS systems, or any inductive or capacitive load, the kW to VA calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your electrical design and analysis.
content.exampleText: 5 kW at PF 0.8: VA = (5 × 1000) / 0.8 = 6250 VA. 10 kW at PF 0.9: VA = (10 × 1000) / 0.9 = 11111 VA. 2 kW at PF 1.0 (resistive load): VA = (2 × 1000) / 1.0 = 2000 VA. 3.5 kW at PF 0.85: VA = (3.5 × 1000) / 0.85 = 4118 VA. A 7.5 kW motor at PF 0.75 requires (7.5 × 1000) / 0.75 = 10000 VA apparent power supply.

items.question: What is the formula to convert kW to VA?
items.answer: The formula is VA = (kW × 1000) / PF, where VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, kW is real power in kilowatts, and PF is the power factor (0 to 1). Real power equals apparent power times power factor, so apparent power is real power divided by power factor.

items.question: What is the difference between kW and VA?
items.answer: kW (kilowatts) is real power—the actual work done by the load (e.g. mechanical output, heat, light). VA (volt-amperes) is apparent power—the total power delivered by the source, including reactive power that does not do useful work. VA ≥ kW always; they are equal only when power factor is 1.0 (purely resistive load).

items.question: What is power factor and what values are typical?
items.answer: Power factor (PF) is the ratio kW / VA, ranging from 0 to 1. It measures how efficiently electrical power is converted to useful work. Typical values: resistive heaters ~1.0, fluorescent lights 0.5–0.95, induction motors 0.7–0.9, power supplies 0.6–0.95. Lower PF means higher VA is required for the same kW, increasing conductor and transformer size.

items.question: Why do I need to convert kW to VA?
items.answer: Transformers, generators, UPS units, and circuit breakers are rated in VA (or kVA), not kW. A load drawing 10 kW at PF 0.8 requires 12.5 kVA of supply capacity. Sizing equipment by kW alone (ignoring PF) can lead to overload. Converting kW to VA ensures you select equipment with sufficient apparent power capacity.

content.heading: How to Convert kW to kVA
content.paragraph1: Converting kilowatts (kW) to kilovolt-amperes (kVA) is essential in electrical engineering and power systems. Kilowatts represent real power—the actual work done by an electrical load—while kilovolt-amperes represent apparent power—the total power delivered by the source, including both real and reactive components. The conversion requires the power factor (PF), which is the ratio of real power to apparent power. Our free kW to kVA calculator provides instant, accurate conversions for sizing equipment, transformers, and generators.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: kVA = kW / PF, where kVA is apparent power in kilovolt-amperes, kW is real power in kilowatts, and PF is the power factor (a value between 0 and 1). For example, a 5 kW load with a power factor of 0.8 requires 5 / 0.8 = 6.25 kVA of apparent power. A lower power factor means higher apparent power is needed to deliver the same real power. The power factor indicates how efficiently the electrical system converts apparent power to useful work: a PF of 1.0 (unity) is 100% efficient; lower values indicate reactive power losses.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is critical in many applications: sizing transformers and generators to ensure adequate capacity for real loads, designing electrical distribution systems and UPS units, calculating circuit breaker and conductor ratings, understanding motor and inductive load behavior, and planning power capacity for commercial and industrial facilities. Knowing how to convert kW to kVA helps you select correctly sized equipment, avoid overloading, and optimize energy efficiency.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts kilowatts and power factor as inputs, applies the formula kVA = kW / PF, and outputs apparent power in kilovolt-amperes. Whether you are working with motors, transformers, generators, UPS systems, or any inductive or capacitive load, the kW to kVA calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your electrical design and analysis.
content.exampleText: 5 kW at PF 0.8: kVA = 5 / 0.8 = 6.25 kVA. 10 kW at PF 0.9: kVA = 10 / 0.9 = 11.11 kVA. 2 kW at PF 1.0 (resistive load): kVA = 2 / 1.0 = 2 kVA. 3.5 kW at PF 0.85: kVA = 3.5 / 0.85 = 4.12 kVA. A 7.5 kW motor at PF 0.75 requires 7.5 / 0.75 = 10 kVA apparent power supply.

items.question: What is the formula to convert kW to kVA?
items.answer: The formula is kVA = kW / PF, where kVA is apparent power in kilovolt-amperes, kW is real power in kilowatts, and PF is the power factor (0 to 1). Real power equals apparent power times power factor, so apparent power is real power divided by power factor.

items.question: What is the difference between kW and kVA?
items.answer: kW (kilowatts) is real power—the actual work done by the load (e.g. mechanical output, heat, light). kVA (kilovolt-amperes) is apparent power—the total power delivered by the source, including reactive power that does not do useful work. kVA ≥ kW always; they are equal only when power factor is 1.0 (purely resistive load).

items.question: What is power factor and what values are typical?
items.answer: Power factor (PF) is the ratio kW / kVA, ranging from 0 to 1. It measures how efficiently electrical power is converted to useful work. Typical values: resistive heaters ~1.0, fluorescent lights 0.5–0.95, induction motors 0.7–0.9, power supplies 0.6–0.95. Lower PF means higher kVA is required for the same kW, increasing conductor and transformer size.

items.question: Why do I need to convert kW to kVA?
items.answer: Transformers, generators, UPS units, and circuit breakers are rated in kVA, not kW. A load drawing 10 kW at PF 0.8 requires 12.5 kVA of supply capacity. content.heading: How to Convert kWh to Watts
content.paragraph1: Converting kilowatt-hours (kWh) to watts (W) is a common calculation when analyzing energy consumption and determining power ratings. Kilowatt-hours represent energy—the total amount of work done over time—while watts represent power—the rate at which energy is consumed or delivered. The conversion requires knowledge of the time duration over which the energy was consumed or delivered. Our free kWh to Watts calculator provides instant, accurate conversions for your electrical and energy calculations.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: Watts = (kWh × 1000) / hours, where kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, hours is the time duration, and Watts is power. For example, if a device consumes 2 kWh of energy over 4 hours, the average power is (2 × 1000) / 4 = 500 watts. This calculation is essential for understanding the power rating of devices, analyzing electricity bills, sizing electrical systems, and comparing energy efficiency of different appliances.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is critical in many applications: determining the wattage of appliances from energy consumption data, calculating power requirements for electrical circuits, analyzing electricity usage patterns, sizing batteries and power supplies, understanding energy efficiency ratings, and estimating operating costs. For example, if your electricity meter shows 5 kWh consumed over 10 hours, the average power draw was (5 × 1000) / 10 = 500 watts. This helps identify high-consumption devices and optimize energy usage.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts kilowatt-hours and time duration as inputs, applies the formula Watts = (kWh × 1000) / hours, and provides the power in watts. Whether you're analyzing household energy consumption, sizing solar systems, calculating battery discharge rates, or comparing appliance efficiency, our kWh to Watts calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your energy management and electrical design needs.
content.exampleText: 2 kWh over 4 hours: Watts = (2 × 1000) / 4 = 500 W. 5 kWh over 10 hours: Watts = (5 × 1000) / 10 = 500 W. 0.5 kWh over 2 hours: Watts = (0.5 × 1000) / 2 = 250 W. 10 kWh over 24 hours: Watts = (10 × 1000) / 24 = 416.67 W. If a device uses 3.6 kWh in 12 hours, the average power is (3.6 × 1000) / 12 = 300 W.

items.question: What is the formula to convert kWh to Watts?
items.answer: The formula is Watts = (kWh × 1000) / hours, where kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, hours is the time duration, and Watts is power. This converts energy consumed over time to average power. For example, 2 kWh over 4 hours equals (2 × 1000) / 4 = 500 watts.

items.question: What is the difference between kWh and Watts?
items.answer: kWh (kilowatt-hours) is energy—the total amount of work done over time, measured in your electricity bill. Watts (W) is power—the rate at which energy is consumed or delivered at any moment. Think of it like distance vs. speed: kWh is like miles traveled, watts is like miles per hour. 1 kWh equals 1000 watts used for 1 hour.

items.question: Why do I need the time duration for this conversion?
items.answer: Energy (kWh) and power (watts) are related by time. The same energy can be delivered at different power levels depending on the time: 2 kWh over 1 hour is 2000 watts, but 2 kWh over 4 hours is only 500 watts. Without knowing the time, you cannot determine the power rating.

items.question: How can I use this calculator to analyze my electricity bill?
items.answer: If your electricity bill shows you consumed 300 kWh in a month (approximately 720 hours), your average power consumption was (300 × 1000) / 720 = 416.67 watts. This helps you understand your baseline power usage. You can also calculate power for specific appliances: if a device uses 1.5 kWh per day (24 hours), it draws (1.5 × 1000) / 24 = 62.5 watts.

items.answer: Yes, our kWh to Watts calculator is completely free. No registration or payment required. Enter energy in kWh and time in hours to get instant, accurate power results in watts.

content.heading: How to Convert mAh to Wh
content.paragraph1: Converting milliampere-hours (mAh) to watt-hours (Wh) is an essential calculation when evaluating battery capacity and energy storage. Milliampere-hours represent electric charge capacity — how much current a battery can deliver over time — while watt-hours represent actual energy storage — the total electrical energy the battery can provide. The conversion requires knowing the battery voltage, as energy depends on both charge and voltage. Our free mAh to Wh calculator provides instant, accurate conversions for your battery and power management calculations.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: Wh = (mAh × V) / 1000, where mAh is the battery capacity in milliampere-hours, V is the voltage in volts, and Wh is the energy in watt-hours. For example, a 5000 mAh battery at 3.7V contains (5000 × 3.7) / 1000 = 18.5 Wh of energy. This calculation is essential for comparing batteries with different voltages, understanding actual power bank capacity, sizing backup power systems, and calculating device runtime based on energy consumption.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is critical in many applications: comparing power banks and portable chargers with different voltages, calculating actual energy storage in smartphone and laptop batteries, determining backup power capacity for UPS systems, sizing solar battery banks, understanding drone and RC vehicle battery performance, and estimating device runtime from battery specifications. For example, a 10,000 mAh power bank at 3.7V provides (10,000 × 3.7) / 1000 = 37 Wh, but the same 10,000 mAh at 5V provides 50 Wh — significantly more energy despite the same mAh rating.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts milliampere-hours and voltage as inputs, applies the formula Wh = (mAh × V) / 1000, and provides the energy in watt-hours. Whether you're comparing power banks, calculating battery capacity for solar systems, sizing battery backups, estimating charging time, or understanding device energy requirements, our mAh to Wh calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your battery management and energy planning needs.

items.question: What is the formula to convert mAh to Wh?
items.answer: The formula is Wh = (mAh × V) / 1000, where mAh is battery capacity in milliampere-hours, V is voltage in volts, and Wh is energy in watt-hours. This converts electric charge capacity to actual energy storage. For example, 5000 mAh at 3.7V equals (5000 × 3.7) / 1000 = 18.5 Wh.

items.question: What is the difference between mAh and Wh?
items.answer: mAh (milliampere-hours) measures electric charge capacity — how much current a battery can deliver over time. Wh (watt-hours) measures actual energy — the total electrical work the battery can perform. mAh doesn't account for voltage, while Wh does. A 10,000 mAh battery at 3.7V provides 37 Wh, but at 5V provides 50 Wh — same mAh, different energy.

items.question: Why do I need voltage for this conversion?
items.answer: Energy (Wh) depends on both charge (mAh) and voltage (V). The same mAh at different voltages provides different energy. Power = Voltage × Current, so higher voltage means more energy for the same charge capacity. Without knowing voltage, you cannot determine actual energy storage.

items.question: How can I use this calculator to compare power banks?
items.answer: Power banks often list capacity in mAh but may have different internal voltages. Convert both to Wh to compare actual energy. A 10,000 mAh power bank at 3.7V (37 Wh) provides less energy than a 10,000 mAh at 5V (50 Wh). Always compare Wh, not just mAh, for accurate capacity comparison.

items.answer: Yes, our mAh to Wh calculator is completely free. No registration or payment required. Enter battery capacity in mAh and voltage in volts for instant, accurate energy results in Wh.

content.heading: How to Convert VA to Amps
content.paragraph1: Converting volt-amperes (VA) to amperes (A) is a fundamental calculation in electrical engineering and power distribution systems. Volt-amperes represent apparent power — the total power drawn by an electrical circuit — while amperes represent current flow. The conversion requires knowing the voltage and whether you're working with a single-phase or three-phase system. Our free VA to Amps calculator provides instant, accurate conversions for both single-phase and three-phase electrical systems, making your power calculations quick and reliable.
content.paragraph2: The formulas are: For single-phase systems, I = VA / V, where I is current in amperes, VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, and V is voltage in volts. For three-phase systems, I = VA / (√3 × V), where √3 ≈ 1.732. For example, a 5000 VA single-phase load at 230V draws 5000 / 230 = 21.74 amps. The same 5000 VA load in a three-phase 400V system draws 5000 / (1.732 × 400) = 7.22 amps per phase. These calculations are essential for sizing wiring, circuit breakers, and electrical equipment.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is critical in many applications: sizing electrical wiring and conductors, selecting appropriate circuit breakers and fuses, designing electrical distribution panels, calculating cable current capacity, determining voltage drop in circuits, sizing transformers and generators, understanding UPS and inverter current draw, and ensuring electrical safety compliance. For example, if a UPS is rated at 3000 VA and operates at 230V single-phase, it will draw 3000 / 230 = 13.04 amps at full load, helping you select the correct circuit breaker rating.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts volt-amperes and voltage as inputs, allows you to select between single-phase and three-phase systems, applies the appropriate formula (I = VA / V for single-phase or I = VA / (√3 × V) for three-phase), and provides the current in amperes. Whether you're sizing electrical panels, calculating wire ampacity, selecting circuit protection devices, designing power distribution systems, or ensuring code compliance, our VA to Amps calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your electrical engineering needs.
content.exampleText: Single-phase: 5000 VA at 230V = 5000 / 230 = 21.74 A. Three-phase: 10,000 VA at 400V = 10,000 / (1.732 × 400) = 14.43 A. Single-phase: 3000 VA at 120V = 3000 / 120 = 25 A. Three-phase: 15,000 VA at 480V = 15,000 / (1.732 × 480) = 18.04 A. If an office requires 8000 VA at 230V single-phase, the current draw is 8000 / 230 = 34.78 A, requiring at least a 40A circuit breaker.

items.question: What is the formula to convert VA to Amps?
items.answer: For single-phase systems: I = VA / V. For three-phase systems: I = VA / (√3 × V), where I is current in amperes, VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, V is voltage in volts, and √3 ≈ 1.732. The three-phase formula accounts for power distribution across three phases, resulting in lower current per phase for the same total power.

items.question: What is the difference between VA and Amps?
items.answer: VA (volt-amperes) measures apparent power — the total electrical power in a circuit, including both real and reactive components. Amps (amperes) measures current — the flow of electric charge. VA = Volts × Amps. They measure different electrical properties: VA is power, Amps is current flow. You need voltage to convert between them.

items.question: Why is the three-phase formula different?
items.answer: In three-phase systems, power is distributed across three phases. The √3 (1.732) factor accounts for this three-phase distribution, resulting in lower current per phase compared to single-phase. For the same total VA, three-phase systems draw less current per wire, allowing smaller conductors and more efficient power transmission.

items.question: How do I use this for circuit breaker sizing?
items.answer: Calculate the maximum current (amps) from the VA rating and voltage. Add a safety margin (typically 125% per electrical codes). Round up to the next standard breaker size. For example, 5000 VA at 230V = 21.74A. With 125% margin: 21.74 × 1.25 = 27.17A. Use a 30A or 32A breaker. Always follow local electrical codes.

content.heading: How to Convert VA to Watts
content.paragraph1: Converting volt-amperes (VA) to watts (W) is a fundamental calculation in electrical engineering and power systems. VA represents apparent power — the total power in an AC circuit — while watts represent real (active) power, the actual work performed. The conversion requires the power factor (PF), the ratio of real power to apparent power. Our free VA to Watts calculator provides instant, accurate conversions, making load sizing and energy assessments quick and reliable.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: W = VA × PF, where W is real power in watts, VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, and PF is the power factor (0 to 1). For example, 5000 VA at PF 0.8 gives 5000 × 0.8 = 4000 W. At PF 0.9, the same 5000 VA yields 4500 W. Power factor reflects how efficiently equipment uses electricity; resistive loads (heaters, incandescent lamps) often approach 1.0, while motors and inductive loads typically range from 0.7 to 0.9.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is essential for sizing UPS systems, inverters, and generators, estimating actual power consumption from nameplate VA ratings, calculating real power for billing and efficiency studies, selecting circuit breakers and wiring based on real power, and designing backup power and renewable energy systems. For instance, a 3000 VA UPS at 0.8 PF delivers up to 2400 W of real power; knowing this helps match loads and avoid overloading.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts VA and power factor as inputs, applies W = VA × PF, and outputs real power in watts. Whether you are evaluating UPS capacity, comparing equipment efficiency, designing electrical distribution, or ensuring code compliance, the VA to Watts calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your electrical engineering needs.
content.exampleText: 5000 VA at PF 0.8 = 5000 × 0.8 = 4000 W. 10,000 VA at PF 0.9 = 10,000 × 0.9 = 9000 W. 3000 VA at PF 0.85 = 3000 × 0.85 = 2550 W. 8000 VA at PF 1.0 = 8000 W. If an office device is rated 6000 VA at 0.9 PF, real power is 6000 × 0.9 = 5400 W — use this for load calculations and breaker sizing.

items.question: What is the formula to convert VA to Watts?
items.answer: The formula is W = VA × PF, where W is real power in watts, VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, and PF is the power factor (0 to 1). Power factor is required because VA is apparent power; only the fraction given by PF is real power.

items.question: What is the difference between VA and Watts?
items.answer: VA (volt-amperes) measures apparent power — total power in an AC circuit, including real and reactive components. Watts measure real (active) power — the power that does actual work. VA = Volts × Amps; Watts = VA × Power Factor. They differ unless the power factor is 1.0.

items.question: Why is power factor needed for VA to Watts?
items.answer: Apparent power (VA) includes reactive power that does not perform useful work. The power factor indicates what fraction of VA is real power. Without PF, you cannot determine real power from a VA rating. Typical PF values range from about 0.7 to 1.0 depending on the load.

items.question: What is a typical power factor for common loads?
items.answer: Resistive loads (heaters, incandescent lighting) often have PF near 1.0. Motors and inductive loads typically range from 0.7 to 0.9. Computers and SMPS often sit around 0.6–0.9. When unsure, 0.8 is a common assumption for mixed loads.

The conversion requires the power factor (PF), the ratio of real power to apparent power. Our free VA to kW calculator provides instant, accurate conversions, making load sizing and energy assessments quick and reliable.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: kW = (VA × PF) / 1000, where kW is real power in kilowatts, VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, and PF is the power factor (0 to 1). For example, 10,000 VA at PF 0.8 gives (10,000 × 0.8) / 1000 = 8 kW. At PF 0.9, the same 10,000 VA yields 9 kW. Power factor reflects how efficiently equipment uses electricity; resistive loads often approach 1.0, while motors and inductive loads typically range from 0.7 to 0.9.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is essential for sizing UPS systems, inverters, and generators, estimating actual power consumption from nameplate VA ratings in kW, calculating real power for billing and efficiency studies, selecting circuit breakers and wiring based on real power, and designing backup power and renewable energy systems. For instance, a 15,000 VA UPS at 0.8 PF delivers up to 12 kW of real power; knowing this helps match loads and avoid overloading.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts VA and power factor as inputs, applies kW = (VA × PF) / 1000, and outputs real power in kilowatts. Whether you are evaluating UPS capacity, comparing equipment efficiency, designing electrical distribution, or ensuring code compliance, the VA to kW calculator delivers accurate, instant results for your electrical engineering needs.
content.exampleText: 10,000 VA at PF 0.8 = (10,000 × 0.8) / 1000 = 8 kW. 20,000 VA at PF 0.9 = 18 kW. 5000 VA at PF 0.85 = 4.25 kW. 25,000 VA at PF 1.0 = 25 kW. If an office device is rated 12,000 VA at 0.9 PF, real power is (12,000 × 0.9) / 1000 = 10.8 kW — use this for load calculations and breaker sizing.

items.question: What is the formula to convert VA to kW?
items.answer: The formula is kW = (VA × PF) / 1000, where kW is real power in kilowatts, VA is apparent power in volt-amperes, and PF is the power factor (0 to 1). Power factor is required because VA is apparent power; only the fraction given by PF is real power, and we divide by 1000 to get kilowatts.

items.question: What is the difference between VA and kW?
items.answer: VA (volt-amperes) measures apparent power — total power in an AC circuit, including real and reactive components. kW (kilowatts) measures real (active) power — the power that does actual work. VA = Volts × Amps; kW = (VA × Power Factor) / 1000. They differ unless the power factor is 1.0 and you account for the 1000 factor.

items.question: Why is power factor needed for VA to kW?
items.answer: Apparent power (VA) includes reactive power that does not perform useful work. The power factor indicates what fraction of VA is real power. Without PF, you cannot determine real power from a VA rating. Typical PF values range from about 0.7 to 1.0 depending on the load.

items.question: What is a typical power factor for common loads?
items.answer: Resistive loads (heaters, incandescent lighting) often have PF near 1.0. Motors and inductive loads typically range from 0.7 to 0.9. Computers and SMPS often sit around 0.6–0.9. When unsure, 0.8 is a common assumption for mixed loads.

content.heading: How to Convert VA to kVA
content.paragraph1: Converting volt-amperes (VA) to kilovolt-amperes (kVA) is a straightforward unit conversion. VA and kVA both measure apparent power — the total power in an AC circuit. The only difference is scale: 1 kVA = 1000 VA. No power factor is required, since we are converting between two units of the same quantity. Our free VA to kVA calculator gives instant, accurate results for sizing UPS systems, transformers, and electrical equipment.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: kVA = VA / 1000. For example, 5000 VA = 5 kVA, 10,000 VA = 10 kVA, and 2500 VA = 2.5 kVA. Apparent power (VA or kVA) is the product of voltage and current; it includes both real power (watts) and reactive power (VAR). Equipment nameplates often list capacity in VA or kVA — converting between them is essential for comparing ratings and ensuring proper load matching.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is used when sizing uninterruptible power supplies (UPS), transformers, and generators; comparing nameplate ratings given in VA vs kVA; simplifying calculations where large apparent-power values are easier to work with in kVA; and ensuring consistency in electrical drawings, specs, and load schedules. For instance, a 15,000 VA UPS is equivalent to 15 kVA; both describe the same apparent power capacity.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts VA as input, applies kVA = VA / 1000, and outputs the result in kilovolt-amperes. Whether you are evaluating UPS capacity, checking transformer ratings, or preparing electrical documentation, the VA to kVA calculator provides fast, reliable conversions with no sign-up or cost.
content.exampleText: 5000 VA = 5 kVA. 10,000 VA = 10 kVA. 2500 VA = 2.5 kVA. 20,000 VA = 20 kVA. 7500 VA = 7.5 kVA. A device rated 12,000 VA has an apparent power of 12 kVA — use this for UPS selection, transformer sizing, or panel load calculations.

items.question: What is the formula to convert VA to kVA?
items.answer: The formula is kVA = VA / 1000. Since both VA and kVA measure apparent power, you simply divide volt-amperes by 1000 to get kilovolt-amperes. No power factor or other inputs are needed.

items.question: What is the difference between VA and kVA?
items.answer: VA (volt-amperes) and kVA (kilovolt-amperes) both measure apparent power. The difference is scale: 1 kVA = 1000 VA. It is the same physical quantity, just expressed in different units, like meters vs kilometers.

items.question: Do I need power factor to convert VA to kVA?
items.answer: No. Power factor is only needed when converting between apparent power (VA/kVA) and real power (watts/kW). Since VA and kVA are the same type of quantity, the conversion is simply divide by 1000.

items.question: When would I use VA vs kVA?
items.answer: Smaller equipment and circuits are often rated in VA (e.g. hundreds or low thousands). Larger systems — UPS, transformers, generators — are typically rated in kVA. Converting VA to kVA lets you compare or add ratings given in different units.

content.heading: How to Convert Amps to kVA
content.paragraph1: Converting amperes (A) to kilovolt-amperes (kVA) is a fundamental calculation in electrical engineering and power systems. Amperes represent electrical current, while kVA represents apparent power. The conversion requires knowledge of voltage (V). Unlike real power (kW), apparent power (kVA) does not require a power factor, making this conversion straightforward. Our free Amps to kVA conversion calculator makes this process quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results for your electrical calculations.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formula is: kVA = (A × V) / 1000, where A is the current in amperes, V is the voltage in volts, and kVA is the apparent power in kilovolt-amperes. Apparent power represents the total power in an electrical circuit, combining both real power (watts) and reactive power (VARs). This is different from real power (kW), which only accounts for the actual work being done.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in various applications: sizing transformers and generators, calculating apparent power requirements, designing electrical distribution systems, determining circuit breaker and fuse ratings, understanding electrical load characteristics, and working with residential, commercial, and industrial electrical systems. Knowing how to convert Amps to kVA helps you make informed decisions about electrical system design, equipment selection, and power management.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes the amperes and voltage as inputs, automatically applies the conversion formula, and provides the result in kilovolt-amperes. The calculator handles both single-phase and three-phase calculations (for three-phase, use line-to-line voltage). Whether you're working with transformers, generators, motors, or any electrical equipment, our Amps to kVA calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: If you have a device drawing 20 amperes at 230 volts, the apparent power in kVA would be: kVA = (20 A × 230 V) / 1000 = 4600 / 1000 = 4.6 kVA. For a device drawing 15 amperes at 120 volts: kVA = (15 A × 120 V) / 1000 = 1800 / 1000 = 1.8 kVA. For a three-phase system with 30 amperes at 400 volts line-to-line: kVA = (30 A × 400 V) / 1000 = 12000 / 1000 = 12 kVA.

items.question: What is the formula to convert amps to kVA?
items.answer: The formula to convert amperes (A) to kilovolt-amperes (kVA) is: kVA = (A × V) / 1000, where A is the current in amperes, V is the voltage in volts, and kVA is the apparent power in kilovolt-amperes.

items.question: Do I need to know the voltage to convert amps to kVA?
items.answer: Yes, voltage is required for the conversion. The apparent power (kVA) depends on both current (amps) and voltage. Common voltages include 120V, 230V, 240V, 380V, and 400V depending on your location and application.

items.question: What is the difference between kVA and kW?
items.answer: kVA (kilovolt-amperes) represents apparent power, which is the total power in an electrical circuit. kW (kilowatts) represents real power (active power), which is the actual work being done. The relationship between them is: kW = kVA × PF, where PF is the power factor. kVA is always equal to or greater than kW.

items.question: Do I need power factor to convert amps to kVA?
items.answer: No, power factor is not required to convert amps to kVA. The formula kVA = (A × V) / 1000 only requires current (amps) and voltage. Power factor is only needed when converting between real power (kW) and apparent power (kVA).

items.answer: Yes, you can use this calculator for three-phase systems. For three-phase calculations, use the line-to-line voltage (not phase voltage). For example, for a 400V three-phase system, use 400V in the calculator.

items.question: Do I need to know the voltage to convert amps to VA?

content.heading: How to Calculate Voltage from Amps and Resistance (Ohm's Law)
content.paragraph1: Calculating voltage (V) from current in amperes (A) and resistance in ohms (Ω) is a fundamental application of Ohm's Law in electrical engineering and electronics. Ohm's Law states that the voltage across a conductor is equal to the current through it multiplied by its resistance: V = I × R. This relationship is essential for circuit analysis, component selection, and troubleshooting. Our free Amps to Volt calculator applies Ohm's Law instantly, giving you accurate voltage results from current and resistance.
content.paragraph2: The formula is: V = I × R, where V is the voltage in volts, I is the current in amperes, and R is the resistance in ohms. Voltage represents the electrical potential difference that drives current through a circuit. Resistance opposes the flow of current. Together, these three quantities are always related by Ohm's Law in resistive circuits—whether DC or AC (using magnitude). Knowing any two, you can find the third.
content.paragraph3: This calculation is used in many applications: designing and analysing DC and AC circuits, sizing conductors and load resistance, selecting fuses and protection devices, troubleshooting electrical faults, teaching electronics and electrical fundamentals, and working with resistors, heating elements, and LED circuits. Understanding how to find voltage from amps and resistance helps you design safe, efficient electrical systems and diagnose problems quickly.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator accepts current (amps) and resistance (ohms) as inputs, applies V = I × R, and displays the voltage in volts. It works for any resistive load. Whether you're a student, technician, or engineer, our Amps to Volt calculator delivers precise results for your electrical calculations.
content.exampleText: If a circuit has a current of 5 A through a resistance of 24 Ω, the voltage is: V = 5 A × 24 Ω = 120 V. For 0.5 A through 460 Ω: V = 0.5 A × 460 Ω = 230 V. For 10 A through 12 Ω: V = 10 A × 12 Ω = 120 V.

items.question: What is the formula for amps to volt?
items.answer: The formula is Ohm's Law: V = I × R, where V is voltage in volts, I is current in amperes, and R is resistance in ohms. To find voltage from amps and resistance, multiply current by resistance.

items.question: Do I need resistance to convert amps to voltage?
items.answer: Yes. Voltage cannot be found from current alone. Ohm's Law requires either resistance (V = I × R) or, in power calculations, voltage and power (but then you are not 'converting' amps to volts). For V = I × R, you must know both amps and ohms.

items.question: Does Ohm's Law apply to AC circuits?
items.answer: Ohm's Law V = I × R applies to resistive AC circuits when using the magnitude of voltage, current, and resistance. For reactive components (inductors, capacitors), you need impedance (Z) instead of R: V = I × Z.

items.question: What units are used for resistance?
items.answer: Resistance is measured in ohms (Ω). The calculator expects resistance in ohms. Common values range from milliohms (mΩ) for conductors to kilohms (kΩ) or megohms (MΩ) for resistors—use the numeric value in ohms (e.g. 1000 for 1 kΩ).

items.question: Can I use this for battery or supply voltage?
items.answer: Yes. If you know the current drawn by a load and its resistance, you can find the voltage across it with V = I × R. For a battery supplying a resistive load, this gives the voltage across the load (approximately the battery voltage when internal resistance is small).

content.heading: How to Convert Volts to Amps
content.paragraph1: Converting voltage (V) to current in amperes (A) is a fundamental electrical calculation. You can do it in two ways: (1) Volts to amps with watts: if you know power P in watts and voltage V, use I = P / V. (2) Volts to amps with ohms: if you know voltage V and resistance R in ohms, use Ohm's Law I = V / R. Both formulas are widely used in circuit design, load sizing, and troubleshooting. Our free Volts to Amps calculator supports both modes — select your calculation, enter the values, and get instant results.
content.paragraph2: With watts: I = P / V. Example: 2300 W at 230 V gives I = 2300 / 230 = 10 A. With ohms: I = V / R (Ohm's Law). Example: 12 V across 24 Ω gives I = 12 / 24 = 0.5 A. Current is the flow of electric charge; voltage is the potential difference that drives it. Resistance opposes current. In resistive DC or AC (magnitude) circuits, these three quantities are related by V = I × R, so I = V / R when you know V and R.
content.paragraph3: Use volts-to-amps with watts when you have a device's power rating (e.g. 100 W bulb at 230 V) and want to know the current draw. Use volts-to-amps with ohms when you know the voltage across a resistor and its resistance, or when designing LED circuits, heating elements, or series/parallel resistive loads. Both methods help size fuses, wires, and power supplies, and are essential for safe electrical design.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator lets you choose "Volts to amps with watts" or "Volts to amps with ohms." Enter voltage (and either watts or ohms), then calculate. Results are in amperes (A). No sign-up required. Whether you're a student, technician, or engineer, the Volts to Amps calculator delivers accurate current values for your electrical calculations.
content.exampleText: With watts: 230 V, 1150 W → I = 1150 / 230 = 5 A. 120 V, 1440 W → I = 12 A. With ohms: 24 V, 48 Ω → I = 24 / 48 = 0.5 A. 230 V, 46 Ω → I = 5 A. A 60 W lamp at 120 V draws 60 / 120 = 0.5 A. A 12 V battery across 6 Ω draws 12 / 6 = 2 A.

items.question: What is the formula for volts to amps with watts?
items.answer: I = P / V, where I is current in amperes, P is power in watts, and V is voltage in volts. Divide power by voltage to get current. Example: 2300 W at 230 V → I = 10 A.

items.question: What is the formula for volts to amps with ohms?
items.answer: I = V / R (Ohm's Law). I is current in amperes, V is voltage in volts, R is resistance in ohms. Divide voltage by resistance to get current. Example: 12 V across 24 Ω → I = 0.5 A.

items.question: When should I use watts vs ohms?
items.answer: Use watts when you know the power (e.g. appliance rating) and voltage. Use ohms when you know the voltage across a resistive load and its resistance, e.g. resistors, heating elements, or simple DC circuits.

items.question: Does Ohm's Law apply to AC?
items.answer: I = V / R applies to resistive AC circuits when using the magnitudes of voltage, current, and resistance. For reactive components (inductors, capacitors), use impedance Z: I = V / Z.

content.heading: How to Convert Volts to Watts
content.paragraph1: Converting voltage (V) and current (A) to power in watts (W) is a fundamental electrical calculation. The relationship is given by the power formula: P = V × I, where P is power in watts, V is voltage in volts, and I is current in amperes. This formula applies to DC circuits and resistive AC circuits. Our free Volts to Watts calculator makes this conversion quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results.
content.paragraph2: The formula P = V × I is one of the most basic in electrical engineering. Voltage represents the electrical potential difference that drives current through a circuit; current is the flow of electric charge. Multiplying them gives the rate at which energy is consumed or delivered—power in watts. For example, 230 V and 10 A give P = 230 × 10 = 2300 W (2.3 kW). For AC circuits with reactive components, power factor may be needed; for simple resistive loads, P = V × I is sufficient.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is used in many applications: calculating power consumption of devices, sizing circuit breakers and wiring, designing electrical circuits, determining load requirements, and understanding electrical system behavior. Whether you work with residential, commercial, or industrial systems, converting volts and amps to watts is essential for safe and efficient electrical design.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes voltage and current as inputs, applies P = V × I, and displays the result in watts. No registration required. Whether you're a student, electrician, or engineer, the Volts to Watts calculator delivers accurate results for your electrical calculations.
content.exampleText: 230 V and 5 A gives P = 230 × 5 = 1150 W. 120 V and 10 A gives P = 1200 W. 24 V and 2 A gives P = 48 W. A 230 V appliance drawing 4.35 A consumes 230 × 4.35 ≈ 1000 W (1 kW).

items.question: What is the formula to convert volts to watts?
items.answer: The formula is P = V × I, where P is power in watts, V is voltage in volts, and I is current in amperes. Multiply voltage by current to get power. Example: 230 V × 10 A = 2300 W.

items.question: Do I need both voltage and current?
items.answer: Yes. Power (watts) depends on both voltage and current. You cannot find watts from voltage alone or current alone; you need both.

items.question: Does this work for AC circuits?
items.answer: Yes, P = V × I applies to DC circuits and resistive AC circuits. For AC with reactive components (inductors, capacitors), use P = V × I × PF where PF is the power factor. For heaters, incandescent lights, and simple resistive loads, P = V × I is accurate.

items.question: What is the difference between volts, amps, and watts?
items.answer: Volts (V) measure voltage—electrical potential difference. Amps (A) measure current—flow of electric charge. Watts (W) measure power—rate of energy use. The relationship is Watts = Volts × Amps.

content.heading: How to Convert Volts to Kilowatts
content.paragraph1: Converting voltage (V) and current (A) to power in kilowatts (kW) is essential in electrical engineering. The formula depends on the system type: DC, single phase AC, or three phase AC. For DC: kW = V × I / 1000. For single phase AC: kW = V × I × PF / 1000, where PF is the power factor. For three phase AC: kW = √3 × V × I × PF / 1000, with V as line-to-line voltage. Our free Volts to kW calculator supports all three modes and gives instant, accurate results.
content.paragraph2: DC (direct current) has no power factor; real power equals voltage times current. Single and three phase AC systems often have reactive loads (motors, ballasts), so only a fraction of apparent power (VA) is real power (kW). The power factor (0 to 1) represents that fraction. For three phase, the √3 factor (about 1.732) accounts for the phase relationship between line-to-line voltage and phase quantities. Common voltages: 120V, 230V, 240V (single phase); 400V, 480V (three phase line-to-line).
content.paragraph3: This conversion is used for: sizing generators and inverters, calculating load in kW from measured V and A, designing distribution systems, specifying breakers and cables, and energy audits. Whether you work with batteries and DC loads, residential single phase, or industrial three phase, converting volts and amps to kilowatts is fundamental for safe and efficient electrical design.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator lets you choose DC, single phase, or three phase. Enter voltage and current; for AC, enter power factor (default 0.8). The result is in kilowatts (kW). No registration required. For students, electricians, and engineers, the Volts to kW calculator delivers accurate results across all common system types.

items.question: What is the formula for volts to kW (DC)?
items.answer: For DC: kW = V × I / 1000, where V is voltage in volts, I is current in amperes. Divide the product by 1000 to get kilowatts. Example: 24 V × 50 A = 1200 W = 1.2 kW.

items.question: What is the formula for single phase AC?
items.answer: For single phase AC: kW = V × I × PF / 1000. V is voltage (volts), I is current (amps), PF is power factor (0 to 1). Example: 230 V, 10 A, PF 0.8 → 230 × 10 × 0.8 / 1000 = 1.84 kW.

items.question: What is the formula for three phase AC?
items.answer: For three phase AC: kW = √3 × V × I × PF / 1000. V is line-to-line voltage (volts), I is line current (amps), PF is power factor. √3 ≈ 1.732. Example: 400 V, 20 A, PF 0.9 → √3 × 400 × 20 × 0.9 / 1000 ≈ 12.47 kW.

items.question: When do I use DC vs single vs three phase?
items.answer: Use DC for batteries, solar DC circuits, and DC loads. Use single phase for typical residential (120V, 230V, 240V). Use three phase for industrial and commercial distribution (400V, 480V line-to-line) and motors.

content.heading: How to Convert Amps to Watts
content.paragraph1: Converting amperes (A) to watts (W) is a fundamental calculation in electrical engineering and power systems. Amperes represent electrical current, while watts represent real power (active power). The conversion requires knowledge of voltage (V). This is one of the most basic electrical calculations, following the power formula: P = I × V, where P is power in watts, I is current in amperes, and V is voltage in volts. Our free Amps to Watts conversion calculator makes this process quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results for your electrical calculations.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formula is: W = A × V, where W is the power in watts, A is the current in amperes, and V is the voltage in volts. This formula applies to DC (direct current) circuits and resistive AC (alternating current) circuits. For AC circuits with reactive components, you may need to consider power factor, but for basic resistive loads, this simple formula provides accurate results. Voltage represents the electrical potential difference that drives current through a circuit, and when multiplied by current, gives the power consumed or delivered.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in various applications: calculating power consumption of electrical devices, sizing circuit breakers and fuses, designing electrical circuits and wiring, determining power requirements for appliances, understanding electrical load characteristics, and working with residential, commercial, and industrial electrical systems. Knowing how to convert Amps to Watts helps you make informed decisions about electrical system design, equipment selection, and energy management.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes the amperes and voltage as inputs, automatically applies the conversion formula, and provides the result in watts. The calculator handles both DC and AC (resistive) calculations. Whether you're working with motors, heaters, lighting systems, appliances, or any electrical equipment, our Amps to Watts calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: If you have a device drawing 10 amperes at 120 volts, the power in watts would be: W = 10 A × 120 V = 1200 W (1.2 kW). For a device drawing 5 amperes at 230 volts: W = 5 A × 230 V = 1150 W (1.15 kW). For a device drawing 20 amperes at 240 volts: W = 20 A × 240 V = 4800 W (4.8 kW).

items.question: What is the formula to convert amps to watts?
items.answer: The formula to convert amperes (A) to watts (W) is: W = A × V, where W is the power in watts, A is the current in amperes, and V is the voltage in volts. This is the basic power formula for DC circuits and resistive AC circuits.

items.question: Do I need to know the voltage to convert amps to watts?
items.answer: Yes, voltage is required for the conversion. The power (watts) depends on both current (amps) and voltage. Common voltages include 120V, 230V, 240V, 380V, and 400V depending on your location and application.

items.question: Does this formula work for AC circuits?
items.answer: Yes, the formula W = A × V works for DC circuits and resistive AC circuits. For AC circuits with reactive components (inductors, capacitors), you may need to consider power factor: W = A × V × PF, where PF is the power factor. However, for basic resistive loads like heaters and incandescent lights, the simple formula W = A × V is accurate.

items.question: What is the difference between watts and amps?
items.answer: Amps (amperes) represent electrical current - the flow of electric charge. Watts represent power - the rate at which energy is consumed or produced. Voltage is the electrical potential difference. The relationship is: Watts = Amps × Volts. You need both amps and volts to calculate watts.

items.question: Can I use this calculator for three-phase systems?
items.answer: For three-phase systems, the calculation is more complex. For balanced three-phase loads, use: W = √3 × A × V × PF, where V is the line-to-line voltage. However, for single-phase calculations or simple resistive loads, our calculator provides accurate results using W = A × V.

items.question: What is the formula for watts to amps (DC)?
items.answer: For DC: I = P / V, where I is current in amperes, P is power in watts, and V is voltage in volts. Divide power by voltage to get current. Example: 1200 W at 120 V → I = 10 A.

items.question: What is the formula for single phase AC?
items.answer: For single phase AC: I = P / (V × PF). V is voltage (volts), P is power (watts), PF is power factor (0 to 1). Example: 1840 W at 230 V, PF 0.8 → I = 1840 / (230 × 0.8) = 10 A.

items.question: What is the formula for three phase AC?
items.answer: For three phase AC: I = P / (√3 × V × PF). V is line-to-line voltage (volts), P is power (watts), PF is power factor. √3 ≈ 1.732. Example: 8.83 kW at 400 V, PF 0.85 → I = 8830 / (√3 × 400 × 0.85) ≈ 15 A.

items.question: When do I use DC vs single vs three phase?
items.answer: Use DC for batteries, solar DC circuits, and DC loads. Use single phase for typical residential (120V, 230V, 240V). Use three phase for industrial and commercial distribution (400V, 480V line-to-line) and motors.

items.question: How does this relate to amps to watts?
items.answer: Watts to amps (I = P / V) and amps to watts (P = I × V) are inverse operations. Use watts-to-amps when you know power and voltage and need current; use amps-to-watts when you know current and voltage and need power.

content.heading: How to Convert Electron-volts to Volts
content.paragraph1: Converting electron-volts (eV) to volts (V) is a fundamental conversion in physics, particularly in particle physics, atomic physics, and electronics. An electron-volt is a unit of energy equal to the amount of kinetic energy gained by a single electron when it accelerates through an electric potential difference of one volt. This makes the conversion straightforward: 1 eV = 1 V for a single electron. Our free Electron-volts to Volts conversion calculator makes this process quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results for your physics calculations.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formula is: V = eV, where V is the voltage in volts and eV is the energy in electron-volts. This direct 1:1 relationship exists because the electron-volt is defined as the energy gained by an electron when it moves through a potential difference of one volt. The electron-volt is a convenient unit for expressing energies on the atomic and subatomic scale, commonly used in particle physics, atomic physics, and semiconductor physics.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in various applications: particle accelerator physics, semiconductor device physics, atomic and molecular physics, X-ray and gamma-ray energy measurements, electron microscopy, plasma physics, and quantum mechanics calculations. Understanding the relationship between electron-volts and volts helps physicists, engineers, and researchers work with energy scales from atomic transitions to high-energy particle collisions.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes electron-volts as input and provides the equivalent voltage in volts. The calculator handles both small values (common in atomic physics) and large values (common in particle physics). Whether you're working with atomic energy levels, particle accelerators, semiconductor band gaps, or any physics application involving electron energies, our Electron-volts to Volts calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: If you have an energy of 1 electron-volt, the equivalent voltage is: V = 1 eV = 1 V. For 10 electron-volts: V = 10 eV = 10 V. For 1000 electron-volts (1 keV): V = 1000 eV = 1000 V. For 1 million electron-volts (1 MeV): V = 1,000,000 eV = 1,000,000 V.

items.question: What is the formula for converting electron-volts to volts?
items.answer: The formula for converting electron-volts (eV) to volts (V) is: V = eV. This is a direct 1:1 conversion because the electron-volt is defined as the energy gained by an electron when it accelerates through a potential difference of one volt.

items.question: What is an electron-volt?
items.answer: An electron-volt (eV) is a unit of energy equal to approximately 1.602 × 10^-19 joules. It is defined as the amount of kinetic energy gained by a single electron when it accelerates through an electric potential difference of one volt. The electron-volt is commonly used in atomic, nuclear, and particle physics.

items.question: Why is the conversion from electron-volts to volts 1:1?
items.answer: The conversion is 1:1 because the electron-volt is specifically defined as the energy gained by an electron when it moves through a potential difference of one volt. Therefore, 1 eV of energy corresponds exactly to 1 V of potential difference for a single electron.

items.question: What are common electron-volt values in physics?
items.answer: Common electron-volt values range from millielectron-volts (meV) for atomic transitions, to electron-volts (eV) for chemical bonds and visible light photons, to kiloelectron-volts (keV) for X-rays, to megaelectron-volts (MeV) for nuclear reactions, to gigaelectron-volts (GeV) and teraelectron-volts (TeV) for high-energy particle physics.

items.answer: This calculator provides the voltage equivalent for a single electron. For multiple electrons, the total energy would be the number of electrons multiplied by the electron-volt value, but the voltage relationship remains 1 eV = 1 V per electron.

content.heading: How to Convert Watts to kWh
content.paragraph1: Converting watts (W) to kilowatt-hours (kWh) is essential for understanding energy consumption and calculating electricity costs. Watts represent power (the rate at which energy is used), while kilowatt-hours represent energy (the total amount of power consumed over time). The conversion requires knowledge of time, as energy equals power multiplied by time. Our free Watts to kWh conversion calculator makes this process quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results for your energy calculations.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formula is: kWh = (W × h) / 1000, where kWh is the energy in kilowatt-hours, W is the power in watts, and h is the time in hours. This formula directly relates power and energy through time. One kilowatt-hour is equal to 1000 watt-hours (1 kWh = 1000 Wh). This means that if a device operates at 1000 watts (1 kilowatt) for 1 hour, it consumes 1 kilowatt-hour of energy.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in various applications: calculating electricity bills and energy costs, understanding energy consumption of household appliances, designing energy-efficient systems, analyzing power usage over time, working with solar panels and renewable energy systems, and performing energy audits. Knowing how to convert Watts to kWh helps you understand the relationship between power consumption and total energy usage, which is crucial for managing electricity costs and optimizing energy efficiency.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes the watts and time (in hours) as inputs, automatically applies the conversion formula, and provides the result in kilowatt-hours. The calculator handles both small values (common in electronics) and large values (common in power systems). Whether you're calculating the energy consumption of a light bulb, estimating monthly electricity costs, designing solar power systems, or analyzing industrial power usage, our Watts to kWh calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: If a 100-watt light bulb runs for 10 hours, the energy in kWh would be: kWh = (100 W × 10 h) / 1000 = 1 kWh. For a 1500-watt heater running for 2 hours: kWh = (1500 W × 2 h) / 1000 = 3 kWh. For a 60-watt device running for 24 hours: kWh = (60 W × 24 h) / 1000 = 1.44 kWh. For a 2000-watt appliance running for 0.5 hours (30 minutes): kWh = (2000 W × 0.5 h) / 1000 = 1 kWh.

items.question: What is the formula to convert watts to kWh?
items.answer: The formula to convert watts (W) to kilowatt-hours (kWh) is: kWh = (W × h) / 1000, where kWh is the energy in kilowatt-hours, W is the power in watts, and h is the time in hours. One kilowatt-hour is equal to 1000 watt-hours (1 kWh = 1000 Wh).

items.question: What is a watt?
items.answer: A watt (W) is the SI unit of power. It is defined as one joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s). Power represents the rate at which energy is used, produced, or transferred. For example, a 100-watt light bulb uses 100 joules of energy every second.

items.question: What is a kilowatt-hour (kWh)?
items.answer: A kilowatt-hour (kWh) is a unit of energy commonly used for electricity billing. It represents the amount of energy consumed when a device with a power of 1 kilowatt (1000 watts) operates for 1 hour. One kWh equals 3,600,000 joules or 3.6 megajoules.

items.question: Why do I need time to convert watts to kWh?
items.answer: Energy is the total amount of power consumed over time, which depends on both power and time. To convert watts (power) to kilowatt-hours (energy), you need to know how long the power is being used. The formula kWh = (W × h) / 1000 shows that energy equals power multiplied by time, divided by 1000 to convert to kilowatt-hours.

items.question: Can I convert kWh to watts?
items.answer: Yes, you can convert kWh to watts using the formula: W = (kWh × 1000) / h, where W is power in watts, kWh is energy in kilowatt-hours, and h is time in hours. This is the reverse of converting watts to kWh. For example, if a device consumes 2 kWh in 4 hours, the average power is (2 kWh × 1000) / 4 h = 500 watts.

content.heading: How to Convert Joules to Watts
content.paragraph1: Converting joules (J) to watts (W) is a fundamental calculation in physics and electrical engineering. Joules represent energy, while watts represent power (the rate at which energy is used or produced). The conversion requires knowledge of time, as power is energy divided by time. Our free Joules to Watts conversion calculator makes this process quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results for your physics and engineering calculations.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formula is: W = J / s, where W is the power in watts, J is the energy in joules, and s is the time in seconds. This formula directly relates energy and power through time. One watt is defined as one joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s). This means that if a device uses 1 joule of energy in 1 second, it is operating at 1 watt of power.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in various applications: calculating power consumption of electrical devices, understanding energy efficiency and power ratings, designing electrical circuits and systems, analyzing battery capacity and discharge rates, working with renewable energy systems, and performing physics calculations involving energy and power. Knowing how to convert Joules to Watts helps you understand the relationship between energy consumption and power requirements in electrical systems.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes the joules and time (in seconds) as inputs, automatically applies the conversion formula, and provides the result in watts. The calculator handles both small values (common in electronics) and large values (common in power systems). Whether you're working with batteries, motors, heaters, lighting systems, or any device that consumes or produces energy, our Joules to Watts calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: If a device uses 3600 joules of energy in 60 seconds, the power in watts would be: W = 3600 J / 60 s = 60 W. For a device using 1000 joules in 10 seconds: W = 1000 J / 10 s = 100 W. For a device using 500 joules in 5 seconds: W = 500 J / 5 s = 100 W. For a device using 7200 joules in 3600 seconds (1 hour): W = 7200 J / 3600 s = 2 W.

items.question: What is the formula to convert joules to watts?
items.answer: The formula to convert joules (J) to watts (W) is: W = J / s, where W is the power in watts, J is the energy in joules, and s is the time in seconds. One watt is equal to one joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s).

items.question: What is a joule?
items.answer: A joule (J) is the SI unit of energy. It is defined as the amount of work done when a force of one newton moves an object one meter in the direction of the force. One joule is also equal to one watt-second, meaning one watt of power for one second.

items.question: What is a watt?
items.answer: A watt (W) is the SI unit of power. It is defined as one joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s). Power represents the rate at which energy is used, produced, or transferred. For example, a 100-watt light bulb uses 100 joules of energy every second.

items.question: Why do I need time to convert joules to watts?
items.answer: Power is the rate at which energy is used or produced, which means it depends on both energy and time. To convert joules (energy) to watts (power), you need to know how long it takes to use or produce that energy. The formula W = J / s shows that power equals energy divided by time.

items.question: Can I convert watts to joules?
items.answer: Yes, you can convert watts to joules using the formula: J = W × s, where J is energy in joules, W is power in watts, and s is time in seconds. This is the reverse of converting joules to watts. For example, a 100-watt device running for 60 seconds uses 100 W × 60 s = 6000 joules of energy.

content.heading: How to Convert Joules to Volts
content.paragraph1: Converting joules (J) to volts (V) is a fundamental calculation in physics and electrical engineering. Joules represent energy, while volts represent electric potential or voltage. The conversion requires knowledge of electric charge (in coulombs), as voltage is energy divided by charge. Our free Joules to Volts conversion calculator makes this process quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results for your physics and engineering calculations.
content.paragraph2: The conversion formula is: V = J / C, where V is the voltage in volts, J is the energy in joules, and C is the electric charge in coulombs. This formula directly relates energy and voltage through electric charge. One volt is defined as one joule per coulomb (1 V = 1 J/C). This means that if 1 joule of energy is associated with 1 coulomb of charge, the voltage is 1 volt.
content.paragraph3: This conversion is commonly used in various applications: calculating voltage in capacitors and batteries, understanding energy storage in electrical systems, designing electrical circuits and power systems, analyzing battery capacity and energy density, working with electrochemical systems, and performing physics calculations involving energy, charge, and voltage. Knowing how to convert Joules to Volts helps you understand the relationship between energy storage and voltage in electrical systems.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes the joules and electric charge (in coulombs) as inputs, automatically applies the conversion formula, and provides the result in volts. The calculator handles both small values (common in electronics) and large values (common in power systems). Whether you're working with capacitors, batteries, electrochemical cells, or any device that stores electrical energy, our Joules to Volts calculator provides accurate, instant conversions.
content.exampleText: If a capacitor stores 10 joules of energy with a charge of 2 coulombs, the voltage would be: V = 10 J / 2 C = 5 V. For a battery storing 100 joules with 5 coulombs of charge: V = 100 J / 5 C = 20 V. For a system with 50 joules and 10 coulombs: V = 50 J / 10 C = 5 V. For a device with 1000 joules and 100 coulombs: V = 1000 J / 100 C = 10 V.

items.question: What is the formula to convert joules to volts?
items.answer: The formula to convert joules (J) to volts (V) is: V = J / C, where V is the voltage in volts, J is the energy in joules, and C is the electric charge in coulombs. One volt is equal to one joule per coulomb (1 V = 1 J/C).

items.question: What is a joule?
items.answer: A joule (J) is the SI unit of energy. It is defined as the amount of work done when a force of one newton moves an object one meter in the direction of the force. One joule is also equal to one watt-second, meaning one watt of power for one second.

items.question: What is a volt?
items.answer: A volt (V) is the SI unit of electric potential, voltage, or electromotive force. It is defined as one joule per coulomb (1 V = 1 J/C). Voltage represents the electric potential difference between two points in an electrical circuit.

items.question: Why do I need electric charge to convert joules to volts?
items.answer: Voltage is the electric potential energy per unit charge, which means it depends on both energy and charge. To convert joules (energy) to volts (voltage), you need to know the electric charge (in coulombs) associated with that energy. The formula V = J / C shows that voltage equals energy divided by charge.

items.question: What is a coulomb?
items.answer: A coulomb (C) is the SI unit of electric charge. It is defined as the amount of charge transported by a constant current of one ampere in one second. One coulomb is approximately equal to 6.242 × 10^18 elementary charges (electrons or protons).

items.question: Can I convert volts to joules?
items.answer: Yes, you can convert volts to joules using the formula: J = V × C, where J is energy in joules, V is voltage in volts, and C is charge in coulombs. This is the reverse of converting joules to volts. For example, a 12-volt battery with 10 coulombs of charge stores 12 V × 10 C = 120 joules of energy.

content.heading: How to Convert Volts to Joules
content.paragraph1: Converting voltage (V) and electric charge (C) to energy in joules (J) is a fundamental calculation in physics and electrical engineering. The relationship is given by J = V × C, where J is energy in joules, V is voltage in volts, and C is charge in coulombs. One volt is one joule per coulomb (1 V = 1 J/C), so energy equals voltage times charge. Our free Volts to Joules calculator makes this conversion quick and easy, providing instant and accurate results.
content.paragraph2: The formula J = V × C expresses the energy stored when charge Q is moved through a potential difference V. It applies to capacitors (E = ½CV² uses a related form), batteries, and any system where electrical potential energy is stored or released. A 12 V battery supplying 10 C of charge delivers 12 × 10 = 120 J of energy. Charge in coulombs is current × time (C = I × t), so you can also think of J = V × I × t (energy = power × time).
content.paragraph3: This conversion is used for: calculating energy stored in capacitors and batteries, understanding electrochemical cell capacity, designing energy storage systems, physics problems involving potential energy, and electrical engineering calculations. Whether you work with electronics, electrochemistry, or general physics, converting volts and coulombs to joules is essential for energy analysis.
content.paragraph4: Our calculator takes voltage and charge (coulombs) as inputs, applies J = V × C, and displays the result in joules. No registration required. Whether you're a student, engineer, or researcher, the Volts to Joules calculator delivers accurate results for your energy calculations.
content.exampleText: 12 V and 5 C gives J = 12 × 5 = 60 J. 230 V and 0.1 C gives J = 23 J. 1.5 V and 2 C (e.g. a small battery) gives J = 3 J. A capacitor charged to 400 V with 0.01 C stores 400 × 0.01 = 4 J.

items.question: What is the formula to convert volts to joules?
items.answer: J = V × C, where J is energy in joules, V is voltage in volts, and C is electric charge in coulombs. Multiply voltage by charge to get energy. Example: 10 V × 3 C = 30 J.

items.question: Do I need both voltage and charge?
items.answer: Yes. Energy (joules) depends on both voltage and charge. You cannot find joules from voltage alone or charge alone; you need both. The relationship is J = V × C.

items.question: What is a coulomb?
items.answer: A coulomb (C) is the SI unit of electric charge. It is the charge transported by a current of one ampere in one second. One coulomb ≈ 6.242 × 10^18 elementary charges (electrons).

items.question: How does this relate to joules to volts?
items.answer: Joules to volts uses V = J / C (voltage = energy ÷ charge). Volts to joules uses J = V × C (energy = voltage × charge). They are inverse operations. Use joules-to-volts when you have energy and charge; use volts-to-joules when you have voltage and charge.

items.answer: Yes. The Volts to Joules calculator is free. No registration required. Enter voltage and charge in coulombs to get energy in joules instantly.
